article:
A 'granule' is a clast of rock with a particle size of 2 to 4 millimetres based
on the Krumbein phi scale of sedimentology. Granules are generally considered
to be larger than sand (0.0625 to 2 millimetres diameter) and smaller than
pebbles (4 to 64 millimetres diameter). A rock made predominantly of granules
is termed a conglomerate. Folk, R.L. (1980) The Petrology
of Sedimentary Rocks. Austin, Texas, Hemphill Publishing Company. 182 pp. ISBN
0-914696-14-9
